The Arab nations consider a deal with Israel ( as brokered by the US) as a buffer against Iran. The resolution to the question therefore depends on the actions of Iran. The potential of war (fatalities) appears to be imminent at any time.

Given the current historically positive relational climate RE Israel and its Arab neighbors(1) I find it highly unlikely that Israel will jeopardize the goodwill it has fostered by instigating regional violence. While I think Hezbollah has an incentive to stir up tensions in the region, given that it is largely externally funded by Iran and Syria(2), who are currently grappling with COVID and a recent civil war respectively, I think the organization presently lacks the operational funding to risk a heavy Israeli military response at present.

To say that tensions in the Middle East are high, would be an understatement and disservice to everyone involved. I cannot think of a time when issues were not likened to a dumpster fire, not in my lifetime at least. The recent explosion in Beirut is the reason behind the current tensions.

It is likely that there will be some type of skirmish between Lebanon and Israel. It could only be a few gun shots, rockets or some random soldiers exchanging gunfire. They are neighboring nations with a long history of fighting with irreconcilable religious and cultural differences. Both nations have interest in maintaining and patrolling their borders. Recently the maritime border has been in the spotlight as well.

The Confrontation between Hezbollah and Israeli forces have gone back and forth for some time now, with various depictions released in the media. The Jerusalem Post describe how the actual war is being fought through the media and propaganda (Jerusalem Post, 2020). This fight can be seen through Al Jazeera reports that showcase false victories from official Israeli media accounts (Al Jazeera, 2020). According to Israel, they were able to thwart an attack from Hezbollah, while Hezbollah completely denied the attack and it was just a way to create propaganda. These reports not only increase tension between the groups, but it also escalates the possibility of an actual attack. Although the attack did not happen, analysts suggest that the fighting is not over, especially as Hezbollah seeks revenge (Haaretz, 2020). One of the last notable encounters between the two groups was in August when Israel hits Hezbollah compound in Lebanon after a short exchange of fire (Washington Post, 2020). As the battle between Hezbollah and Israeli forces have resulted in fatalities in the past, neither sides are a stranger to combat, however, most of the focus seems to be on fighting with propaganda. My predictions are as follows: -20% Yes https://www.jpost.com/middle-east/the-israeli-media-is-at-war-with-hezbollah-analysis-644379 https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/7/28/lebanons-hezbollah-accuses-israel-of-fabricating-border-clash https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-hezbollah-failed-to-attack-israel-but-made-one-significant-achievement-1.9035031 https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/israel-strikes-hezbollah-posts-in-lebanon-after-taking-fire/2020/08/26/e08c2bae-e767-11ea-bf44-0d31c85838a5_story.html

Between 14 November 2020, will there be a lethal confrontation in Lebanon or Israel between the armed forces of Hezbollah and those of Israel? Tensions still remain high between Israel and Hezbollah. Most recently, Hezbollah was very candid with their intensions, “and it vowed to remain committed to fighting Israel, as the country is paralyzed by its worst economic and financial crisis” (Times of Israel, 2020). Hezbollah wants to present a unified and strong front, however there are higher priorities. Covid-19 has required all nations to pay close attention and focus on the virus, “tension between Hezbollah and Israel has risen in recent weeks, at the same time that the coronavirus swept through the region. While both sides are busy combating the pandemic, they are also preparing for the expected continuation of the conflict once the crisis is over, while maintaining the existing balance of deterrence between them” (Mizrahi and Schweitzer, 2020). The conflict has not gone away, and tensions are still high. However, everything that has unfolded because of COVID-19 have caused a drastic change in direction. Both Israel and Hezbollah are working on building up their forces which acts as a means of deterrence. Hezbollah has been stockpiling missiles at a rapid rate, “most estimates puts the present number of Hezbollah missiles and rockets at over 100,000” (Iddon, 2020). Hezbollah, while fighting has been limited, has been able to still build their military force. While most tactics have been described as deterrence and proxy wars, there have been some deadly attacks, “Israel had been bracing for retaliation from Hezbollah since the killing of one of its operatives in a strike in Syria last week that was attributed to Israel” (Kershner, 2020). While both sides blame each other for the hostile actions, “no casualties were reported by either side” (Kershner, 2020). There is a lot of tension but with COVID-19, the troops have been limited. In my opinion, there is an 87% chance that there is not a lethal confrontation in Lebanon or Israel. Mizrahi, O., and Schweitzer, Y. (2020, May 6). The Israel-Hezbollah Confrontation amidst the Coronavirus Crisis. INSS. Retrieved from: https://www.inss.org.il/publication/israel-hizbollah-and-the-coronavirus/ Agencies and TOI Staff. (2020, September 29). Defying Macron, Hezbollah says it will continue to fight Israel. The Times of Israel. Retrieved from: https://www.timesofisrael.com/defying-macron-hezbollah-says-it-will-continue-to-fight-israel/ Iddon, P. (2020, Jun 27). In A Third Lebanon Warm Israel Will Have To Contend With Increasingly Lethal Hezbollah Missiles. Forbes. Retrieved from: https://www.forbes.com/sites/pauliddon/2020/06/27/in-a-third-lebanon-war-israel-will-have-to-contend-with-increasingly-lethal-hezbollah-missiles/#31e98c984b5e Kershner, I. (2020, July 27). Israel Says It Thwarted a Hezbollah Raid at Lebanon Border. The New York Times. Retrieved from: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/27/world/middleeast/israel-hezbollah-lebanon-fighting.html

dropping with the passage of time.
Dropping as news is slim.
I define a lethal confrontation as one that results in a military fatality and/or civilian casualty.

Yes, I assess that there is a 56% chance that constant skirmishes along the border of Lebanon and Israel will result in further casualties among both military and civilian populations prior to 14 November 2020. On August 25, Israel carried out air attacks on Hezbollah observation posts in Lebanon. This came as a response to a security incident that occurred at the border. The activity was later identified as gunshots directed at IDF troops. Israel and Lebanon are still technically at war, and the United Nations force UNIFIL is tasked with monitoring the ceasefire. An incident a month earlier occurred when two drones packed with explosives targeted the group's stronghold in south Beirut. An additional confrontation unfolded when supposed Hezbollah fighters attempted to sneak across the border. On August 29th, Israeli tanks carried out strikes against Hamas posts in the Gaza Strip in response to the previous day’s launching of airborne incendiary devices into Israel, which sparked at least 23 fires in the south of the country. While not devastating, this attack against Israel was coordinated with a manifesto calling for a long-term campaign against their enemies by Hezbollah. Public relations between the two parties have also evaporated due to the UAE and Israel's announcement to normalized relations, a decision which is seen by Lebanon as a serious threat. Hezbollah later condemned Bahrain’s move to normalize Israel ties on September 12. Hezbollah is the world’s most heavily armed non-state actor per the Center for Strategic and International Studies. They possess manpower capabilities which are estimated at 30,000 fighters with a reservist corps that could draw upon another 10,000 to 20,000 combatants. In addition, they possess extensive technology such as surface to air missiles. Israel’s military stands at roughly 169,500, including 102,500 conscripts; however, they are spears across a larger area and are forced to be more defensive. Thus, Hezbollah will continue to utilize similar patterns and tactics to instigate violence along the border. Hezbollah is facing a major internal crisis in the shape of government mismanagement and years of slow growth which has saddled Lebanon with one of the world’s highest public debt burdens. Protests have erupted spending several religious and cultural backgrounds. In August 2020, when an UN-backed tribunal found Salim Jamil Ayyash, a Hezbollah affiliate, guilty of the 2005 assassination of former Lebanese Prime Minister Rafiq Hariri. This further factor has placed Hezbollah in a position where their very survival as an organization may be dependent on regaining prestige through the use of violence. Therefore, the trend of violence will with a moderate degree of certainty result in the death of a member of one of these two sides prior to November 14th. Sources https://www.cfr.org/backgrounder/what-hezbollah https://www.jpost.com/breaking-news/lebanons-hezbollah-condemns-bahrain-move-to-normalize-israel-ties-642035 https://www.timesofisrael.com/hamas-hezbollah-leaders-meet-to-discuss-israeli-ties-with-arab-world/#gs.fz7gnq https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/08/israel-launches-air-attacks-hezbollah-posts-lebanon-border-200826061432456.html https://www.timesofisrael.com/israeli-tanks-strike-hamas-posts-in-gaza-in-response-to-arson-balloons/#gs.fz6t8k https://www.cfr.org/event/future-us-israel-relations-symposium https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Counting-the-Cost-FINAL.pdf

There has been an ongoing proxy war since 2000 which has led to a build-up of tensions between nations. It seems like something will happen to cause a lethal conflict but I do not believe that this will happen before the 14th of November this year. I do think lethal conflict will take place at some point but not in the near future. I predict that there is a 25% chance of deadly conflict will happen between nations before November 14th. https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/27/world/middleeast/israel-hezbollah-lebanon-fighting.html https://www.airuniversity.af.edu/Portals/10/JEMEAA/Journals/Volume-02_Issue-1/Eilam.pdf

This proxy war has been occurring since 2000 which establishes a long period of tension. Although it seems as if a lethal confrontation is inevitable, I do not believe there is a high chance of this occurring prior to 14 November 2020. I believe there is a 35% chance that a lethal confrontation in Lebanon or Israel between the armed forces of Hezbollah and those of Israel will occur.

Since this has been posted, there has already been a lethal confrontation at the border that resulted in fatalities. There was a border clash at the Northern Border of Israel, and following there was also an Israeli missile strike that killed a Hezbollah member. Since these two events, these two sides have rapidly mobilized and have exchanged missile and artillery fire. So, yes there will continue to be lethal confrontation between Israel and Hezbollah.

Initially, we predicted that there is a high chance of lethal confrontation in Lebanon or Israel between the armed forces of Hezbollah and those of Israel. There have already been a few conflicts between these forces since this assignment was posted. On August 25, 2020 gunfire was exchanged between the two at the border, which resulted in Israeli counter-attacks. Also, on September 22, a Hezbollah stronghold in Lebanon was hit with an explosion.

There has been ongoing conflict since Israel invaded southern Lebanon going after Hezbollah. Lebanon seems uninterested in helping to root out Hezbollah. The possibilities of an attack increase over time due to constant tensions that are not being addressed.

"Hezbollah, armed and backed by Iran, has more than 100,000 rockets and has been increasing its investments in drones and precision-guided missiles. Israel has also been increasing its investments in high-tech defence systems to counter the threat, including the famed 'iron dome' system that shoots down rockets, drones and other threats. Investment in defensive systems is only part of how Israel is preparing for the possibility of a future conflict. It is also readying infantry and armoured units to confront enemy threats. [...] To make forces more lethal on the battlefield Israel has invested in these kinds of drills to make infantry and tanks work more closely together. This was one of the lessons learned from previous conflicts in Lebanon or Gaza: slow-moving units that don't communicate run into trouble. The last ten years have been all about reforming and learning from those experiences." https://www.meforum.org/61606/israel-prepares-to-take-on-hezbollah

Mostly because of historical precedent, the tension between these two factions has no reason to deescalate. Irregular forces involved in an armed conflict increase the likelihood of confrontations materializing. The situation in Lebanon, worsened by the port explosion may serve as a trigger to reignite attacks conducted by Hezbollah against Israeli forces.

This conflict has been ongoing since 2000 with both sides provoking the other and making claims that the other has performed atrocities against the other or has a means to destroy one another. I think that this conflict will continue to be a proxy war with some accidental deaths by airstrike or by pure mishap like what occurred when the Hezbollah fighter died in an airstrike in Syria.

Before 14 November 2020, there is a moderate probability there be a lethal confrontation in Lebanon or Israel between the armed forces of Hezbollah and those of Israel. I think that there will be a lethal confrontation between the armed forces. There is currently a lot of bad blood between Lebanon and Israel. The term lethal confrontation is a low bar. As someone else pointed out, one has to define "lethal confrontation", does that mean all-out war or invasion from either party or just a cross boarder shooting or grenade attach that kills one person? There have been several recent attacks with no casualties reported, but lethal action is not overwhelmingly likely but probable. Seems there is always some tension and form of fighting on the boarder, but no one is taking ownership of small attacks. A small lethal confrontation is likely before mid-November as both sides are assessing the other and building up for bigger attacks. The tensions will likely build into greater bloodshed. I am about 55 % convinced that some form of lethal confrontation will occur between the two armed forces. The two nations seem to definitely be poised for conflict, but I believe the bomb in Lebanon in early August has given the Lebanese a lot more to worry about than Israel, as they are still reeling from that explosion.

The Hezbollah is located in Lebanon and they want revenge against Israel for the death of their leader. There is a 65% chance that there will be a lethal confrontation in Israel before 14 November, 2020 because of past disputes.

With Syria's civil war looking without end and a general stalemate between the Iranian and Iraeli-American forces there is unlikely that Hezbollah will commit to disruptive attacks unless they wish to retaliate or find an advantage they can exploit.

I give this a 95% probability to result in a lethal confrontation because both sides are the aggressor in this situation. Israel and Lebanon will not back down from a fight. The two sides are set to meet on 10 OCT to discuss the maritime border, but the likelihood of a conflict breaking out is high in my opinion. https://www.timesofisrael.com/israel-and-lebanon-to-launch-direct-maritime-border-talks-report-say

Because Israel Already Thwarted a Hezbollah Raid at Lebanon Border according to this article back on July 27, 2020. https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/27/world/middleeast/israel-hezbollah-lebanon-fighting.html

There is a lot of bad blood between Lebanon and Israel right now. They are "fighting" but no one is taking ownership of small attacks. It is likely that both are sizing each other up for bigger attacks along with gathering intelligence. The tensions will likely build into greater bloodshed. https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/blast-levels-hezbollah-linked-site-in-southern-lebanon/2020/09/22/3a97fb12-fcdc-11ea-830c-a160b331ca62_story.html

I am unconvinced that lethal confrontation will occur between the two nations before this date. One has to define "lethal confrontation", does that mean all-out war or invasion from either party? There have been several attacks with no casualties reported, as stated in the articles below, but lethal action is not overwhelmingly likely. The two nations seem to definitely be poised for conflict, but I believe the bomb in Lebanon in early August has given the Lebanese a lot more to worry about than Israel, as they are still reeling from that explosion. Lethal action or all-out war seems inevitable, but not at the moment.

Given that Israel and Hezbollah have been fighting very regularly for quite some time both diplomatically and violently, I am almost certain this will happen. Recently though, the leader of the Hezbollah stated that they would not be drawn into a war. Given the instability of this region, I am not so sure of this claim. It is more likely that a lethal confrontation will be had through Hezbollah backed proxies. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-lebanon-israel-hezbollah-idUSKBN25Q0EI

Before 14 November 2020, will there be a lethal confrontation in Lebanon or Israel between the armed forces of Hezbollah and those of Israel? I think that there will be a lethal confrontation between the armed forces because in July there was an airstrike in SYria. In August there were shots fired in Lebanon which increased the tensions between Israel and Hezbollah. Hezbollah’ subjective is the distribution of Israel and in the last two months they were attacked twice by their adversaries. I think there is a 70% chance that there will be lethal confrontation. https://www.arabnews.com/node/1717476 https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/3-israeli-tanks-breach-lebanese-border/1938281

Tensions between Israel and the Hezbollah remain high, even after the border skirmish in July and the missile strikes weeks before. Hezbollah’s main goal is to free the Lebanon area of Israel occupation as they claim, and such a goal is unlikely to be accomplished without violence. Israel is stern in maintaining its defense of the region, and the country backing down is very unlikely.

Delphi Method led our train of thought on this one. Our initial estimate sat at low probability and rounded was 47.5% yes, it would be a lethal confrontation. Our research automatically showed us that our prediction was 100% right because there was a lethal confrontation. The Good Judgment post was posted August 14 and the “inevitable” attack that was promised happened on August 25, 2020. Additionally, a Hezbollah stronghold was hit with an explosion that caused both panic and left buildings damaged. It is believed to have belonged and originated with Israeli forces. This attack happened on September 22. Our final prediction is at 100% yes.

With tensions at consistently in a high manor, the risk of lives being lost remains high. Israel has already launched an air strike on Hezbollah and killed their leader. They have retaliated with a remark saying they will avenge his death. This action has not been taken yet but with the US election coming up soon, I predict action will occur in the coming weeks. Both sides have already shown they are not afraid to use military force or launch a strike. Because of these circumstances, I believe there it will become fatal to soldiers on both sides.

I believe there will be another armed infraction between Israel and Hezbollah, particularly during an election year. When president Trump froze finds President Obama agreed to pay the PLO and moved the US embassy to Jerusalem, he in fact sent a message that Jerusalem and the contested area along the Golan Heights belonged to the Jews and not the Muslims. When in fact Jews, Christians and Muslims all lay claim to the city as the origins of their religions. Additionally, continuous defensive actions by Israel in a completely surrounded stance guarantees continued US involvement on Middle Eastern affairs, military support to Israeli military forces and Muslim discontent for western influence in a religious argument.

There have been multiple instances where each country has fired upon each other, but it has not resulted in a war. I say there is a 50% chance that there is another lethal confrontation in Lebanon or Israel. Each country is relying on military deterrence to keep each other from firing first. Neither one them wants to fire upon each other because that would bring up the threat of war, but in past months there have been multiple instances of each side firing upon one or other because a country has stepped out of place.

I predict that there is a 90% chance of there being confrontation in Lebanon because there are still active reports being pushed out about missile strikes on Hezbollah outposts in Lebanon. Israel Defense Forces said “During operational activity in northern Israel last night, shots were fired from Lebanon toward IDF troops. We responded with fire, & our aircraft struck Hezbollah observation posts near the border,”. Lebanon and Israel are theoretically still at war so I believe that the chances are high of there being a lethal confrontation. https://www.thedefensepost.com/2020/08/26/israeli-air-strikes-hezbollah/

Tensions have been extremely high in late 2020 between Hezbollah and Israel. In July Israel killed Hezbollah’s commander in an airstrike. Hezbollah has already stated that they will avenge this death. Israel also took the strong initiative to strike Hezbollah targets after a bombing on Golem Heights was stopped. Israel is obviously not afraid to show their intolerants of any Hezbollah activity. Israel will not hesitate to launch any attack they see necessary to protect their people. On the other hand, both of these attacks were on Syrian soil. It will also be very dumb for Hezbollah to attack on Israel soil, but it has happened before. The more likely outcome is that Israel will directly cripple Hezbollah in Lebanon as a result of more violent actions toward Israely ideals. High tensions have already resulted in a skirmish on the Israely-Lebanon border when both sides exchanged fire and closed roads. Although no lives were lost on either side, this could very easily result in a bloody battle. The real question is, “Will Hezbollah make direct action to threaten Israel?” If this occurs, Israel will attempt to put down this threat immediately, which will result in casualties.

I predict there is a 35% chance that there will be a lethal confrontation between Hezbollah and Israel before 14 November. Netanyahu has stated that although both sides have political difficulties, “Israel doesn’t want a large-scale confrontation with Hezbollah at this time”. Furthermore, Israel and Hezbollah are aware of the consequences of a large lethal confrontation. Predictions reason that recent tensions could result in minor conflict, yet both sides will try to “limit” them. Blanford summarized that the consequences of a Third Lebanon War would result in “the greatest destruction and loss of life since the 1948 war, and Lebanon will be turned into a car park”. Although Hezbollah has the capability to invade Northern parts of Israel, they know the resulting war would destroy Lebanon, and likely Hezbollah with it. Because reports show that neither side is searching for Lethal conflict, I predict there is a 35% chance of such conflict occurring before 14 November.

I say this prediction because Israel launched an airstrike previously and Hezbollah stated that a counterattack was coming, that attack has yet to come. So therefore I say that there is a chance that this attack will come before Nov. 14. Yet also there is the chance that Israel stops the attack prior to it actually coming in and hurting anyone.

I predict a 70% chance of a lethal confrontation between Hezbollah and Israel prior to 14 November 2020, determined by observing current tensions and attack trends between the two groups. On 20 July 2020, a Hezbollah fighter was killed by an IDF airstrike, leading Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah to vow revenge in the form of the deaths of Israeli soldiers. According to the IDF, since the 20 July airstrike, Hezbollah has attempted to cross the U.N established "Blue Line" border and has shot at Israeli soldiers, increasing tensions between the belligerents. Hezbollah's "equation of deterrence" policy makes it likely that more retaliatory attacks will occur, likely resulting in Israeli casualties. Even if deaths do not occur for Israel, they will likely respond with airstrikes. This assertion is based on how Israel has responded to recent Hezbollah incursions; shots fired at Israeli soldiers in August lead to multiple airstrikes against Hezbollah positions. Hezbollah's desire for revenge couples with Israeli responses leads me to predict a 70% of a lethal confrontation before 14 November.

Near the end of August, a single isolated incident occurred between the two forces on the Lebanon border, but this resulted in zero casualties. By definition, this was a confrontation but not a lethal one. Since then, there have been no other incidents and surprisingly Israel is set to hold mediated talks with Lebanon over their maritime border disputes. There is no certainty that these talks will result in an agreement between the two countries, but it is a hopeful step in the right direction that for now points towards a period of peace. Given the trajectory of current events towards mediation, coupled with their lack of diplomatic relations and current state of war, the chance for a lethal confrontation to break out is about even at this time. Much of this hinges on the success of the upcoming mediated peace talks.

I seriously doubt that there will be a loss of life in the next 48 days due to the Israeli Lebanese conflict. On 26 Sept. according to ABC News "Israel will hold rare talks with Lebanon next month in an effort to resolve a longstanding maritime border dispute, an Israeli official said Saturday." These talks will apparently be U.S. mediated and I doubt that the talks will conclude before 14 November. On the off chance that the talks do finish before 14 November, I doubt that any military action will be taken in the following days. https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/israel-hold-us-mediated-talks-lebanon-sea-border-73264009

Hezbollah is stuck on a strategic deterrence dilemma due to a consequence of recent events and its own ill-advised declarations. Khomeinist-Shiite organization's leadership, sworn to Israsel's destruction, has declared that it will retaliate for any Isreali action against its personnel. In July there was an Israeli strike in SYria that killed a Hezbollah operative which triggered retaliation by the Hezbollah. However, Hezbollah actions are constrained by its inability to withstand consequences of escalation. Israeli-Hezbollah conflict is complex and they have very different objectives. Hezbollah wants to destroy Israel and Israel wants to prevent its own destruction. Therefore I believe that there is a chance that the Hezbollah will just not care what happens to them and confront Israel, but I don't think that Israel would start anything. I also do not believe that it is likely that Hezbollah will be confident enough in themselves to actually press forward against Israel. https://www.algemeiner.com/2020/09/18/hezbollah-caught-in-the-horns-of-a-deterrence-dilemma/

When an apparent Israeli airstrike killed a Hezbollah member in July 2020, the terrorist group stated that a retaliatory attack was “inevitable.” On August 25, 2020, shots were fired at Israeli border positions from within Lebanon, leading to Israeli counter attacks on Hezbollah lookout posts. Given that this attack happened after the Good Judgement question was posted on August 14, I assigned it a 100% chance of attack. Also, on September 22, a Hezbollah stronghold in Lebanon was hit with an explosion that damaged buildings and caused widespread civilian panic. The blast coincided with “intense Israeli overflights that did not leave the area,” which gives a high probability that the blast came from Israeli forces.

I believe that it is fairly unlikely that Lebanon and Israel will have a lethal confrontation. These relations of these two countries have become more intense over the past couple of months, but I find it unlikely that Lebanon would find the motive to create any type of confrontation. Israel is far more fit to combat Lebanon. Lebanon has virtually no air strength, while Israel has some of the most technologically advanced aircraft in the Middle East region. While tension may be at a high level, Lebanon will be unable to respond on any level, unless they were aided significantly by surrounding countries. therefore if Lebanon were to attack it would be via ground or missile, and Lebanon still doesn't have the fire power to do so.

I predict that it is pretty improbable that Hezbollah and Israel will have a lethal confrontation before 14th of November. Many articles are saying that in past encounters nobody has been really injured yet I find it improbable that it escalates that quickly. However, all it takes is one slip up or attack to spring these tensions into motion. Lebanon and Israel have had a long history of conflict ever since Israel's inception. Multiple conflicts have been fought over a span of more than 70 years, with many casualties, both military and civilian, occurring on both sides. Tensions flare on and off, but 2020 has seen a particularly harsh spike in aggressiveness. Several missile and drone strikes have already rocked both countries in 2020, with the most recent being a missile strike on a Hezbollah (A Lebanese sponsored militia and the main opponent of Israel) stronghold on 22 September. No casualties were officially reported from the blast, but it shows that both sides are willing to escalate the conflict further. Both sides have agreed to mediated negotiations, but it is unlikely that the conflict will be resolved.

Hezbollah is seen as a major threat to Israel, but they seem as if they are in a sort of standoff with Israel. According to reports, "some 150,000 missiles targeting Israeli civilians", meaning Hezbollah has the power to attack, but for some unknown reason has not tried to. The odds Hezbollah actually attacks Israel is low, because of the blow back Hezbollah will get from Israel's allies, namely the United States of America. Hezbollah will not risk an attack on the United States, but nothing is outside the realm of possibility. https://www.politico.eu/article/the-eu-must-ban-hezbollah-lawmakers-warn-in-transatlantic-unison/

According to Sherman Kent, in the book "SuperForecasting" by Phillip Tetlock I believe the probability will be a 32% chance which would be in the area of "Probably not" in terms of not likely to happen. The tensions are intense between Lebanon and Israel however I do not believe that Hezbollah will try to initiate attacks into Israel because Israel would be too powerful of a force for Lebanon to try and attack. Although the two countries were in a major conflict in 2006 and there have been airstrikes conducted on both countries, there haven't been any major casualties. In closing, I believe that there will "probably not" be a lethal confrontation between Lebanon and Israel. It will most likely just stay political.

While tensions between Israel and Hezbollah has started to rise higher, people are starting to predict that there will be another war started between the two adversaries. This rivalry started to rise when a Hezbollah soldier was apparently killed by a Israeli airstrike in Syria, which the Prime Minister said they will retaliate against Israel. There have been several airstrikes going between each country but nothing has been fatal. While tensions rise, I predict that this will not lead to a lethal confrontation. This is because there has already been a very lethal confrontation between these two adversaries in 2006 but this war effected both of the participants very negatively. Several thousand Israelis were displaced because of this war, rather it being a lethal confrontation I predict this will just be a show of might for months but then it will lead to political confrontation and discussion. Since neither of these countries want to go to another war with each other and greatly destroy their country.

In my opinion, the chances for an all out war between the two is unlikely. War costs money and lives, and i don't think either side wants to spend money and lives. Tensions are very high and both sides could be ready for it in an instant, but it seems as thought neither side is going to do anything unless the other does. there have been drone strikes and small retaliations here and there but i don't think all out war is in the forecast. Both sides also respect each others military might, and although they do hate each other, they still don't want have all those lives be lost.

The Situation in Lebanon is very shaky and unknown, with two forces (Israel and Hezbollah) known to be aggressive and vengeful. Efforts to establish a functioning government in Lebanon have not been successful, and the world is now watching. With this instability, border skirmishes are possible, and small mistakes by soldiers on the ground can cause large conflicts. Lebanon is one of the most corrupt governments in the world, and its people have been in protest since the blast; the Hezbollah may see this as an opportunity to wage more covert terrorist attacks against Israel and gain more control in the Lebanon Parliament in which they control thirteen seats. I would reduce 3 percent of my forecast every day until November 14th.

Overall, Israel’s and Hezbollah's relationship is built upon mutual deterrence. Both sides have proclaimed multiple threats and have taken many threatening actions against one another. Israel has launched dozens of preemptive drone strikes on Irainian/Hezbollah targets in Syria. Then along the border of Lebanon, there is a vast amount of Israeli forces stationed in order to prevent any further attack from Hezbollah militants. Along this border Israel has deterred a number of small attacks from Hezbollah forces, but has decided to not pursue them into Lebanon. All of these actions from Israel are strictly preemptive and are based on Israel’s desire to only protect its people and interests. In all, Israel does not want to escalate the conflict with Hezbollah in order to avoid unnecessary conflict. Presently, Hezbollah has been reluctant in escalating the conflict due to their fear of inferiority to the Israeli military and their incapability to launch a large scale attack. In addition, the US has placed sanctions on Libanese forums and leaders that have ties to Hezbollah. To summarize, both sides have high tension between each other and it is very likely that a lethal confrontation will occur. Nevertheless, Israel is at somewhat of a stand still, and Hezbollah forces do not currently have the means to cause any paramount harm to the Israeli military. https://www.algemeiner.com/2020/09/18/hezbollah-caught-in-the-horns-of-a-deterrence-dilemma/ https://www.thedefensepost.com/2020/08/31/hezbollah-israel-soldiers/ https://www.cnn.com/2006/WORLD/meast/07/14/israel.lebanon.timeline/index.html https://www.wionews.com/world/arms-depot-of-hezbollah-explodes-in-lebanon-several-injured-329556

Yes I do believe that there is a chance that there will be a lethal confrontation in Lebanon or Israel between the armed forces of Hezbollah and those of Israel but only about 22% and here are my reasons why. According to The Algemeiner, “Should Hezbollah, alone or in conjunction with Iran or other allies, attain the capability to destroy Israel, it is unlikely that punitive threats would suffice to deter an attack, as Israel’s enemies would accept extremely heavy damage as the price of success in their efforts to annihilate the Jewish State.” According to the Israel Hayom, “Barak adds that it is possible that Haniyeh was trying to reach an agreement with the Iranians about the activity of the Palestinian Islamic Jihad, considered to closest to Iran of all the Palestinian terrorist organizations, after "the escalation following the targeted killing of Baha Abu-Atta [last November] created tension between Hamas and the PIJ." Based upon the information above and what I have learned about the tensions between these nations, I’m sticking with my prediction of there only being about a 22% chance because confrontations would lead to considerable damage and extensive losses and that there is a stronger focus on making peace than causing war. Also, according to Sherman Kent’s probability chart, that is mentioned in the book SUPERFORECASTING, my percentage probability is more towards the general area of possibility being probably not.

The average gap between Hezbollah attacks is 651.3 days. Given that there are 365 days in one year there is a 56 percent chance of an attack in any given year. The question however, specifically mentions a confrontation between Hezbollah and Israeli military forces. Of the attacks referenced in the Stanford CISAC (which is not a comprehensive list) only 2 explicitly mention the Israeli military. If there is an attack, there is a 10 percent historical chance that it will directly involve some kind of Israeli military presence leaving us with a base rate of 5 percent approximately. [1] However, we are also above average in terms of time between attacks. The last attack occurred about 800 days ago. it is probably worth pushing this base rate up to say, for instance, 9 percent.

This is probably a model question for one of those cognitive biases where you think "doesn't this happen all the time, go for twice the consensus or 50%" - and then go back and find that it's actually <50% likely in a given year, far less so in 3 months. Therefore, I like to be lower than the crowd on this one until war is declared, but not by too much - the tank incident referenced in the question demonstrates that one single combatant death on either side is not just a tail risk. Assassinations would count, civilian deaths won't.
